Speaker: Aila Taylor
Name: Aila Taylor
Notes: Aila Taylor worked hard to preserve the North Taranaki reefs. As a result the New Plymouth list includes a number of reefs.

Speaker: Apirana Tuahae Mahuika
Name: Apirana Mahuika
Notes: Api Mahuika was a senior kaumātua of Ngāti Porou, and very supportive of the project, patiently reading the long lists of East Coast names. We recorded in Gisborne, saving me a long trip up the coast.

Speaker: Arapera Mikaera Rangimauriora Nitenetara (Governor)
Name: Arapera Nitenetara
Notes: Mrs Governor was blind, and I read each name for her to repeat/correct, then edited my own voice out.

Speaker: Autiti Wikiriwhi in Wahiao
Name: Autiti Wikiriwhi
Notes: Beaker Wickliffe lived next to Wahiao meeting house, in a house that had half collapsed. It was apparently agreed with his family that he and the house might as well live out their time together.

Speaker: Charles Solomon
Name: Charles Solomon
Notes: Chartes Solomon was the son of Tommy Solomon, the last "full blooded" Moriori of the Chatham Islands. I included him more for his historical importance, with the help of his son Māui Solomon, since he did not speak the Moriori language. It has since undergone a revival. He was blind and I read him each name. He lived in Temuka, and he gave me some sense of what it meant to say the Moriori died "of despair".

Speaker: Euera Manuera
Name: Euera Manuera
Notes: I visited Eruera Manuera one afternoon, and he was nearly asleep. His family told me he was better in the morrning, and so it proved. He died very soon after we recorded the names.

Speaker: Hohepa Toia
Name: Hohepa Toia
Notes: Possibly misidentified as his brother Sam

Speaker: Hone Turei
Name: Hone Turei
Notes: Later Sir Hone.

Speaker: Auntie Jane Manahi
Name: Jane Manahi
Notes: Aunt Jane Manahi was another old-school kuia, beautifully spoken in both English and Māori, who would brook no nonsense from any young whippersnapper.

Speaker: John Henry Bird, QSO in Apa-hapai-taketake
Name: John Bird
Notes: We recorded in the meeting house, and some women were weaving at the other end. I asked if they could stop, but Mr Bird said, no, their work is tapu too.

Speaker: John Rangihau
Location Old: Studio 1 of Broadcasting House, Bowen St, Wellington, of treasured memory (now replaced by a brick banana)
Location: Studio 1, Broadcasting House, Bowen St, Wellington
Name: John Rangihau
Notes: I had known John Rangihou since 1971 and of course he was best qualified to speak for Ngai Tūhoe. It was only by chance that I recorded Waimana without him. It took months to find us both free. We recorded in Studio 1 of Broadcasting House of blessed memory. You can hear his love of the places in his voice. (This is true of many other speakers as well).

Speaker: John Tangiora
Name: John Tangiora
Notes: I recorded John Tangiora in a tearing hurry, having driven from Ruatoki via Murupara and a back road to Taupo and Napier, and he and Pauline had an appointment not long after. He was in failing health.

Speaker: Kara Puketapu
Name: Kara Puketapu
Notes: Kara Puketapu was chosen by Te Ati Awa as their speaker, and uses a strong Taranaki accent with silent Hs. I discussed with him whether he should make some concession to the previous occupants of Wellington Harbour, Ngati Ira and Ngai Tara. He said "We'll see how it goes" or words to that effect. He made some effort to aspirate "Hātaitai", but the effect is uncomfortable.

Speaker: Lena Manuel
Name: Lena Manuel
Notes: Lena Manuel was a stalwart of the Māori Women's Welfare League, and I had met her in that context in Wellington, but in the event we recorded in her home in Wairoa. I always had an uphill job persuading women to speak. My standard line was that women needed to know about placenames in composing waiata. I now wish I had worked harder at it.

Speaker: Maarire Goodall
Location: Studio 1, Broadcasting House, Bowen St, Wellington
Name: Maarire Goodall
Notes: Sir Tīpene O'Regan directed me to Maarire Goodall when I began the South Island. He was invaluable, pointing me towards most of the speakers and taking over the production of the third print volume. We were both strong-willed but eventually resolved all problems. In the course of this, he became a dear friend.

Speaker: Maehe P H Nikora
Location: Studio 1, Broadcasting House, Bowen St, Wellington
Name: Maehe Nikora

Speaker: Aunt Magda Walscott
Name: Magda Walscott
Notes: Magda Walscott was a very senior kuia of her region, but very bright.

Speaker: Mahia Whatarau-Tainui (with Henry Robinson)
Name: Mahia Whatarau-Tainui
Notes: with Henry Robinson

Speaker: Maika Mason (Poutini Ngai Tahu)
Name: Maika Mason
Notes: Poutini Ngai Tahu

Speaker: Major Meihana in Tamatea Pokai Whenua
Name: Major Meihana

Speaker: Malcolm Hoskins
Name: Malcolm Hoskins
Notes: Malcom Hoskins is the youngest speaker.

Speaker: Manahi Paewai
Name: Manahi Paewai
Notes: We recorded in the evening and birdsong adds to the track.

Speaker: Matawha (Pompey) Durie
Name: Matawha Durie
Notes: Mr Durie knew far more names around the family home and Aorangi marae - names for humps and dips in the land, it seemed.

Speaker: Matenga Baker
Name: Matenga Baker
Notes: We recorded Mr Baker on a winter day with a crackling fire.

Speaker: Maurice Wilson in Te Puru o Aorere
Name: Maurice Wilson

Speaker: Mere Toia
Notes: co-speaker with Hohepa Toia and Sam Toia

Speaker: Merimeri Penfold in Tane Nui a Rangi
Name: Merimeri Penfold
Notes: Merimeri was my first tutor of Māori, a great scholar of the language, and a beautiful speaker. She helped update Williams' Dictionary, and translated some of Shakespeare's sonnets into Māori. In 1970 she composed a haka against apartheid. It is my eternal regret that when I asked her to record her Far North names, she brought a male speaker with her, and I let her defer to him, so we only hear her say the names that he missed. I resolved to make a greater effort to include women in the South Island section.

Speaker: Mita Mohi
Name: Mita Mohi
Notes: Mita Mohi is better known as a teacher of the taiaha.

Speaker: Paddy Gilroy (with George Te Au)
Name: Paddy Gilroy
Notes: with George Te Au

Speaker: Pakariki Harrison
Name: Pakariki Harrison
Notes: Paki Harrison is better known as a master-carver.

Speaker: Pukerau Rangitutea in the porch of Hoturoa
Name: Pukerau Rangitutea
Notes: The first recording, at his home in the evening, was a technical disaster for some reason, and I went back later, in the morning, and our recording on the meeting house porch was much more successful. Like many others, he showed his dedication to this project by agreeing undergo the tedious process of recording the names clearly and without background noise, not once but twice.

Speaker: Rameka Cope
Location: Studio 1, Broadcasting House, Bowen St, Wellington
Name: Rameka Cope

Speaker: Raureti Harris
Name: Raureti Harris
Notes: and Bob Harris

Speaker: Rex Hiakita
Name: Rex Hiakita
Notes: When I visited Rex Hiakita, he was hesitant, but a would-be rangatira  from another area (with a very poor outline of a facial moko), said "Give me your machine, I'll record your names." Knowing enough not to say "No" outright, I said "Taihoa" and came back to Mr Hiakita later.

Speaker: Ru Kotua
Name: Ru Kotua
Notes: Ru Kotua initially baulked at recording the names when I showed him a list written in the double-vowel orthography. He wanted nothing to do with it. The first volume was entirely so written in the first instance, and the double vowels were laboriously converted to macrons by the incredibly patient Radio NZ typing pool. When I showed Mr Kotua the version with macrons, he thought they were the greatest thing since sliced bread and all objection evaporated. The recording, outside in a field near Takapau, went happily with birds chirping in the background.

Speaker: Ruka Broughton
Location: his office, Victoria University of Wellington
Name: Ruka Broughton

Speaker: Sam Toia
Name: Sam Toia
Notes: Possibly misidentified as his brother Hohepa

Speaker: Sonny Waru in Stratford Park
Name: Sonny Waru
Notes: Recording western Taranaki was a tossup between Sony Waru and Huirangi Waikerpuru.I didn't know when I chose Sonny Waru that he was only affiliated to Taranaki through Pariʰaka. (His first name, Taniwharau, gives away his Waikato origin.) Nonetheless he has lived there so long his accent is fully Taranaki.

Speaker: Te Aputa ki Wairua Parata Kauri
Name: Te Aputa ki Wairua Kauri
Notes: Mrs Kauri smoked constantly and was short of breath throughout the recording. (She died soon after.) You can hear her pride when she says her ancestor's name, Wi Parata.

Speaker: Te Rino Tirikatene
Name: Te Rino Tirikatene
Notes: Rino Tirikātene was a son of Sir Eruera Tirikātene MP and a brother of Whetū Tirikātene-Sullivan MP. He died while standing for Parliament himself, and his son Rino took the seat. He had no tribal affiliation to the Marton region, but was the best possible person to say the names of the many buildings at Rātana.

Speaker: Turi Elkington
Name: Turi Elkington
Notes: Finding a speaker for Nelson proved difficult, but I had been introduced to Mr Elkington in Waipukurau when I was recording in that area. He had already been enthusiastic for the project, though of course he declined to speak the names so far from his home, so I had no hesitation in going back to him.

Speaker: Waiharakeke (Wai) Waitere
Name: Waiharakeke Waitere
Notes: Mrs Wai Waitere was a kuia of the old school, a wonderfully distinguished lady, who spoke both beautiful English and Māori. We recorded in her villa in Pūtiki.

Speaker: Wiremu Kere Kere
Name: Wiremu Kere Kere
Notes: Wiremu Kere Kere was my starting point in finding the network of speakers. We shared an office suite in Radio NZ Special Projects for several years.

Speaker: Wiremu Parker
Name: Wiremu Parker
Notes: Wiremu Parker was a pioneer of Māori broadcasting. He coined the term 'te reo irirangi' for radio. Because he was unable to speak for his home territory for obscure reasons, I asked him to read the title names. I recorded him outside in the Wellington Botanic Gardens just of Salamanca Road.

Speaker: the Rev Hare Te Raharaha Kake
